article.title: BitChute
article.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]|small=yes}}
{{short description|Peer-to-peer video hosting service}}
{{Infobox website
 | name             = BitChute
 | logo             = BitChute Logo.png
 | logo_alt         = A tilted black square with white text reading "BIT", followed by red text reading "CHUTE"
 | url              = {{URL|https://bitchute.com}}
 | type             = [[Online video platform]]
 | registration     = Optional
 | language         = English
 | author           = Ray Vahey
 | launch_date      = {{start date and age|2017|1}}
 | current status   = Active
 | headquarters     = [[Newbury, Berkshire]], [[England]], United Kingdom 
 | alexa            = {{increase}}  4,816 ({{as of|2019|07|02|alt=July 2, 2019}})<ref name="Alexa Internet">{{cite web |url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/bitchute.com |title= Bitchute.com Traffic, Demographics and Competitors - Alexa |publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190702051444/https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/bitchute.com |archive-date= July 2, 2019 |dead-url= yes }}</ref>
}}

'''BitChute''' is a [[video hosting service]] that uses [[Peer-to-peer (computing)|peer-to-peer]] [[WebTorrent]] technology.<ref name="torrentfreak">{{cite news|url=https://torrentfreak.com/bitchute-is-a-bittorrent-powered-youtube-alternative-170129/|title=BitChute is a BitTorrent-Powered YouTube Alternative|last=Maxwell|first=Andy|date=January 29, 2017|work=[[TorrentFreak]]|access-date=December 10, 2017|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209044057/https://torrentfreak.com/bitchute-is-a-bittorrent-powered-youtube-alternative-170129/|archive-date=December 9, 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref> It was founded as a way to avoid content rules that are enforced on platforms like [[YouTube]],<ref name="torrentfreak" /> and some creators who have been banned or had their channels "[[YouTube#Community policy|demonetized]]" (barred from receiving advertising revenue) on YouTube have migrated to BitChute.<ref name="Daro 2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/ishmaeldaro/right-wing-youtube-alternative-platforms|title=Right-Wing YouTubers Think It's Only A Matter Of Time Before They Get Kicked Off The Site|last=Daro|first=Ishmael N.|date=April 18, 2018|work=[[BuzzFeed News]]|access-date=May 4, 2019|last2=Lytvynenko|first2=Jane|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180705121420/https://www.buzzfeed.com/ishmaeldaro/right-wing-youtube-alternative-platforms|archive-date=July 5, 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref> The platform accommodates [[Far-right politics|far-right]] individuals and [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorists]]{{refn|name="far-right-group"|<ref name="Daro 2019" /><ref name="Schroeder 2019">{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailydot.com/upstream/bitchute/|title=Far-right conspiracy vloggers have a new home|last=Schroeder|first=Audra|date=November 2, 2018|website=[[The Daily Dot]]|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504054532/https://www.dailydot.com/upstream/bitchute/|archive-date=May 4, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 4, 2019}}</ref><ref name="Tani 2017" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/9/16446920/internet-ban-nazis-white-supremacist-hosting-providers-charlottesville|title=Two months ago, the internet tried to banish Nazis. No one knows if it worked|last=Robertson|first=Adi|date=October 9, 2017|website=[[The Verge]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180404073119/https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/9/16446920/internet-ban-nazis-white-supremacist-hosting-providers-charlottesville|archive-date=April 4, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=May 24, 2019|quote=Alt-tech services include alternatives to Reddit (Voat), Patreon (Hatreon), Twitter (Gab), GoFundMe (GoyFundMe), and YouTube (BitChute)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://qz.com/1617824/twitter-facebook-bans-send-alt-right-to-gab-and-telegram/|title=Twitter, Facebook, and Insta bans send the alt-right to Gab and Telegram|last=Livni|first=Ephrat|date=May 12, 2019|website=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190524011611/https://qz.com/1617824/twitter-facebook-bans-send-alt-right-to-gab-and-telegram/|archive-date=May 24, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 24, 2019|quote=The far right have plenty of places to go when they are no longer welcome on mainstream platforms—like Parler, Minds, MeWe, and BitChute, among others.}}</ref>}}; the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] accuses the site of hosting "hate-fueled material".<ref name="Hayden 2019">{{Cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2019/01/11/problem-epik-proportions|title=A Problem of Epik Proportions|last=Hayden|first=Michael Edison|date=January 11, 2019|website=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190112081948/https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2019/01/11/problem-epik-proportions|archive-date=January 12, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=January 12, 2019}}</ref>

== History ==
The company was launched by Ray Vahey in January 2017.<ref name="Schroeder 2019" /> It is based on the peer-to-peer WebTorrent system, a [[JavaScript]] torrenting program that can run in a [[web browser]]. Users who watch a video also [[Seed (BitTorrent)|seed]] it.<ref name="Daro 2019" /> BitChute does not rely on advertising, and users can send payments to video creators directly.<ref name="Alexander 2019">{{Cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2018/3/7/17087668/steemit-dtube-bitchute-youtube-purge|title=Controversial YouTubers head to alternative platforms in wake of ‘purge’|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=March 7, 2018|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504061655/https://www.polygon.com/2018/3/7/17087668/steemit-dtube-bitchute-youtube-purge|archive-date=May 4, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 4, 2019}}</ref>

In November 2018 BitChute was banned from [[PayPal]].<ref name="Blake 2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/14/bitchute-youtube-alternative-cries-foul-over-appar/|title=BitChute, YouTube alternative, cries foul over apparent punt from PayPal|last=Blake|first=Andrew|date=November 14, 2018|work=[[The Washington Times]]|access-date=November 28, 2018|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127015719/https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/14/bitchute-youtube-alternative-cries-foul-over-appar/|archive-date=November 27, 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/11/15/18096027/facebook-nyt-report-morale-definers-sandberg-kaplan|title=Facebook has a growing morale problem|last=Newton|first=Casey|date=November 15, 2018|website=[[The Verge]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504062935/https://www.theverge.com/2018/11/15/18096027/facebook-nyt-report-morale-definers-sandberg-kaplan|archive-date=May 4, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 4, 2019|quote="... the front page was littered with videos about Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, and Pizzagate. It’s unclear what the final straw was."}}</ref> [[Alex Jones]], the [[Proud Boys]], [[Tommy Robinson (activist)|Tommy Robinson]], and several [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascists]] were also banned at the same time.<ref name="Blake 2018"/>

In January 2019, BitChute announced in a post on [[Gab (social network)|Gab]] that they would move their domains over to [[Epik (domain registrar)|Epik]], a small domain registrar known for accepting the registration of websites that host far-right content.<ref name="Hayden 2019" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/story/how-right-wing-social-media-site-gab-got-back-online/|title=How Right-Wing Social Media Site Gab Got Back Online|last=Martineau|first=Paris|date=November 6, 2018|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|access-date=May 4, 2019|issn=1059-1028|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190502214807/https://www.wired.com/story/how-right-wing-social-media-site-gab-got-back-online/|archive-date=May 2, 2019|dead-url=no}}</ref>

== Content ==
BitChute has accommodated [[Far-right politics|far-right]] groups and individuals,<ref name="far-right-group"/> and has been criticized by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] for hosting "hate-fueled material".<ref name="Hayden 2019" /> There has been conflict between YouTube and right-wing video creators over the inclusion of hate speech and misinformation in videos, and YouTube responded in some cases by banning creators, blocking their videos, or through channel "demonetization".<ref name="Daro 2019" /> Vahey has described BitChute as an alternative option to avoid the "bannings, demonetization, and tweaking algorithms to send certain content into obscurity" he views as "increased levels of censorship" by established services like YouTube.<ref name="torrentfreak" /> Some users and groups who have been banned from YouTube have migrated to BitChute, including Alex Jones' far-right conspiracy theory channel ''[[InfoWars]]''.<ref name="Schroeder 2019" /> Other prominent far-right and [[alt-right]] video creators who are not banned from YouTube cross-post their videos to BitChute, including [[Lauren Southern]], [[Stefan Molyneux]], [[Millennial Woes]], and [[Paul Joseph Watson]].<ref name="Daro 2019" /><ref name="Tani 2017">{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/far-right-tech-platforms-gab-youtube-bitchute-2017-9?r=US&IR=T|title='There's no one for right-wingers to pick a fight with': The far right is struggling to sustain interest in its social media platforms|last=Tani|first=Maxwell|date=September 22, 2017|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=December 10, 2017|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208231540/http://uk.businessinsider.com/far-right-tech-platforms-gab-youtube-bitchute-2017-9?r=US&IR=T|archive-date=December 8, 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref>

== See also ==
* [[Comparison of BitTorrent clients]]
* [[Decentralized computing]]
* [[List of video hosting services]]
* [[PeerTube]]

== References ==

{{Reflist}}

== External links ==
* {{Official website|https://BitChute.com}} of BitChute

{{Alt-right|state=collapsed}}
{{Video digital distribution platforms|state=collapsed}}

[[Category:Social media]]

article.title: BitChute
article.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]|small=yes}}
{{short description|Peer-to-peer video hosting service}}
{{Infobox website
 | name             = BitChute
 | logo             = BitChute Logo.png
 | logo_alt         = A tilted black square with white text reading "BIT", followed by red text reading "CHUTE"
 | url              = {{URL|https://bitchute.com}}
 | type             = [[Online video platform]]
 | registration     = Optional
 | language         = English
 | author           = Ray Vahey
 | launch_date      = {{start date and age|2017|1}}
 | current status   = Active
 | headquarters     = [[Newbury, Berkshire]], [[England]], United Kingdom 
 | alexa            = {{increase}}  4,816 ({{as of|2019|07|02|alt=July 2, 2019}})<ref name="Alexa Internet">{{cite web |url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/bitchute.com |title= Bitchute.com Traffic, Demographics and Competitors - Alexa |publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190702051444/https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/bitchute.com |archive-date= July 2, 2019 |dead-url= yes }}</ref>
}}

'''BitChute''' is a [[video hosting service]] that uses [[Peer-to-peer (computing)|peer-to-peer]] [[WebTorrent]] technology.<ref name="torrentfreak">{{cite news|url=https://torrentfreak.com/bitchute-is-a-bittorrent-powered-youtube-alternative-170129/|title=BitChute is a BitTorrent-Powered YouTube Alternative|last=Maxwell|first=Andy|date=January 29, 2017|work=[[TorrentFreak]]|access-date=December 10, 2017|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209044057/https://torrentfreak.com/bitchute-is-a-bittorrent-powered-youtube-alternative-170129/|archive-date=December 9, 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref> It was founded as a way to avoid content rules that are enforced on platforms like [[YouTube]],<ref name="torrentfreak" /> and some creators who have been banned or had their channels "[[YouTube#Community policy|demonetized]]" (barred from receiving advertising revenue) on YouTube have migrated to BitChute.<ref name="Daro 2019">{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/ishmaeldaro/right-wing-youtube-alternative-platforms|title=Right-Wing YouTubers Think It's Only A Matter Of Time Before They Get Kicked Off The Site|last=Daro|first=Ishmael N.|date=April 18, 2018|work=[[BuzzFeed News]]|access-date=May 4, 2019|last2=Lytvynenko|first2=Jane|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180705121420/https://www.buzzfeed.com/ishmaeldaro/right-wing-youtube-alternative-platforms|archive-date=July 5, 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref> The platform accommodates [[Far-right politics|far-right]] individuals and [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorists]]{{refn|name="far-right-group"|<ref name="Daro 2019" /><ref name="Schroeder 2019">{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailydot.com/upstream/bitchute/|title=Far-right conspiracy vloggers have a new home|last=Schroeder|first=Audra|date=November 2, 2018|website=[[The Daily Dot]]|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504054532/https://www.dailydot.com/upstream/bitchute/|archive-date=May 4, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 4, 2019}}</ref><ref name="Tani 2017" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/9/16446920/internet-ban-nazis-white-supremacist-hosting-providers-charlottesville|title=Two months ago, the internet tried to banish Nazis. No one knows if it worked|last=Robertson|first=Adi|date=October 9, 2017|website=[[The Verge]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180404073119/https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/9/16446920/internet-ban-nazis-white-supremacist-hosting-providers-charlottesville|archive-date=April 4, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=May 24, 2019|quote=Alt-tech services include alternatives to Reddit (Voat), Patreon (Hatreon), Twitter (Gab), GoFundMe (GoyFundMe), and YouTube (BitChute)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://qz.com/1617824/twitter-facebook-bans-send-alt-right-to-gab-and-telegram/|title=Twitter, Facebook, and Insta bans send the alt-right to Gab and Telegram|last=Livni|first=Ephrat|date=May 12, 2019|website=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190524011611/https://qz.com/1617824/twitter-facebook-bans-send-alt-right-to-gab-and-telegram/|archive-date=May 24, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 24, 2019|quote=The far right have plenty of places to go when they are no longer welcome on mainstream platforms—like Parler, Minds, MeWe, and BitChute, among others.}}</ref>}}; the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] accuses the site of hosting "hate-fueled material".<ref name="Hayden 2019">{{Cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2019/01/11/problem-epik-proportions|title=A Problem of Epik Proportions|last=Hayden|first=Michael Edison|date=January 11, 2019|website=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190112081948/https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2019/01/11/problem-epik-proportions|archive-date=January 12, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=January 12, 2019}}</ref>

== History ==
The company was launched by Ray Vahey in January 2017.<ref name="Schroeder 2019" /> It is based on the peer-to-peer WebTorrent system, a [[JavaScript]] torrenting program that can run in a [[web browser]]. Users who watch a video also [[Seed (BitTorrent)|seed]] it.<ref name="Daro 2019" /> BitChute does not rely on advertising, and users can send payments to video creators directly.<ref name="Alexander 2019">{{Cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2018/3/7/17087668/steemit-dtube-bitchute-youtube-purge|title=Controversial YouTubers head to alternative platforms in wake of ‘purge’|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=March 7, 2018|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504061655/https://www.polygon.com/2018/3/7/17087668/steemit-dtube-bitchute-youtube-purge|archive-date=May 4, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 4, 2019}}</ref>

In November 2018 BitChute was banned from [[PayPal]].<ref name="Blake 2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/14/bitchute-youtube-alternative-cries-foul-over-appar/|title=BitChute, YouTube alternative, cries foul over apparent punt from PayPal|last=Blake|first=Andrew|date=November 14, 2018|work=[[The Washington Times]]|access-date=November 28, 2018|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127015719/https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/14/bitchute-youtube-alternative-cries-foul-over-appar/|archive-date=November 27, 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/11/15/18096027/facebook-nyt-report-morale-definers-sandberg-kaplan|title=Facebook has a growing morale problem|last=Newton|first=Casey|date=November 15, 2018|website=[[The Verge]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504062935/https://www.theverge.com/2018/11/15/18096027/facebook-nyt-report-morale-definers-sandberg-kaplan|archive-date=May 4, 2019|dead-url=no|access-date=May 4, 2019|quote="... the front page was littered with videos about Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, and Pizzagate. It’s unclear what the final straw was."}}</ref> [[Alex Jones]], the [[Proud Boys]], [[Tommy Robinson (activist)|Tommy Robinson]], and several [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascists]] were also banned at the same time.<ref name="Blake 2018"/>

In January 2019, BitChute announced in a post on [[Gab (social network)|Gab]] that they would move their domains over to [[Epik (domain registrar)|Epik]], a small domain registrar known for accepting the registration of websites that host far-right content.<ref name="Hayden 2019" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/story/how-right-wing-social-media-site-gab-got-back-online/|title=How Right-Wing Social Media Site Gab Got Back Online|last=Martineau|first=Paris|date=November 6, 2018|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|access-date=May 4, 2019|issn=1059-1028|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190502214807/https://www.wired.com/story/how-right-wing-social-media-site-gab-got-back-online/|archive-date=May 2, 2019|dead-url=no}}</ref>

== Content ==
BitChute has accommodated [[Far-right politics|far-right]] groups and individuals,<ref name="far-right-group"/> and has been criticized by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] for hosting "hate-fueled material".<ref name="Hayden 2019" /> There has been conflict between YouTube and right-wing video creators over the inclusion of hate speech and misinformation in videos, and YouTube responded in some cases by banning creators, blocking their videos, or through channel "demonetization".<ref name="Daro 2019" /> Vahey has described BitChute as an alternative option to avoid the "bannings, demonetization, and tweaking algorithms to send certain content into obscurity" he views as "increased levels of censorship" by established services like YouTube.<ref name="torrentfreak" /> Some users and groups who have been banned from YouTube have migrated to BitChute, including Alex Jones' far-right conspiracy theory channel ''[[InfoWars]]''.<ref name="Schroeder 2019" /> Other prominent far-right and [[alt-right]] video creators who are not banned from YouTube cross-post their videos to BitChute, including [[Lauren Southern]], [[Stefan Molyneux]], [[Millennial Woes]], and [[Paul Joseph Watson]].<ref name="Daro 2019" /><ref name="Tani 2017">{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/far-right-tech-platforms-gab-youtube-bitchute-2017-9?r=US&IR=T|title='There's no one for right-wingers to pick a fight with': The far right is struggling to sustain interest in its social media platforms|last=Tani|first=Maxwell|date=September 22, 2017|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=December 10, 2017|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208231540/http://uk.businessinsider.com/far-right-tech-platforms-gab-youtube-bitchute-2017-9?r=US&IR=T|archive-date=December 8, 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref>
